instruction: Write a professional email to: caambrosecchia@gmail.com
input: Subject: Fwd: CARS Final Appeal
output:
*Adam Peacock*


---------- Forwarded message ---------
From: Tom Gore <tgore@yahoo.com>
Date: Wed, Oct 1, 2025 at 11:05 AM
Subject: Re: CARS Final Appeal
To: apeacock@aqorn.com <apeacock@aqorn.com>


I have evidence, emails and documents contradicting much of what you
claim.  You WERE identified and documented as CFO.  You also had full
access to the bank accounts and even had your own financial software
solution which I never had access to.

If I get summoned for anything related to this, you can be assured you will
be contacted and all evidence will be surrendered proving my points.


On Wednesday, October 1, 2025 at 10:46:27 AM CDT, Adam Peacock <
alawson@aqorn.com> wrote:


Hello Tom,

I understand you may be seeking closure but here are some things to keep in
mind:

   - The Texas SOS always had the same 3 officers/directors as when you
   first created the charity organization: Tom G, JJ and Yasser
   - I never held any official title with regard to anything
   financial-related or otherwise and the TX SOS will confirm; the last known
   individual who accepted the role of Treasurer/CFO was Tom Baird
   - The concept of Directors was informal and referred to anyone willing
   to lend a hand which included over 20 individuals, possibly more
   - I was never involved with fund collection; money went to you
   - I was never involved with any disbursements; It was paid by you
   - I was not a signer on the bank account but was only given read-only
   access to the bank app
   - I was not involved with contracts or sponsorship agreements outside
   trying to draft example language that could *potentially* be used
   - The 1-2 occurrences where I generated receipts was exclusively at your
   direction

I cannot and will not assist in anything outside my knowledge or duty.

*Adam Peacock*


On Wed, Oct 1, 2025 at 8:40 AM Tom Gore <tgore@yahoo.com> wrote:

Adam

I have asked you multiple times to close the books out for CARS since you
were the CFO.  I had resigned my position 2 weeks prior to you and tried to
collaborate with you to close the charity down properly.  You refused to
assist in any way.

I am unaware of any pending audits or outstanding issues and don't expect
any but I had hoped to file appropriate tax returns this year and do things
by the book but can not do so without your assistance.

If I do not hear back from you, I will assume your stance is the same as
you told me in February, that you will not assist.  In the event any
further actions or notices may surface, I will direct them to you.

Regards
Tom

instruction: Write a professional email to: caambrosecchia@gmail.com
input: Subject: Re: CARS Final Appeal
output:
Thoughts/suggestions on wording below?

Tom,
I understand you may be seeking closure but here are some things to keep in
mind:


   - The Texas SOS always had the same 3 officers/directors as when you
      first created the charity organization. Tom, JJ and Yasser
      - I never held any official title with regard to anything
      financial-related or otherwise and the TX SOS will confirm; the
last known
      individual who accepted the role of Treasurer/CFO was Tom Baird
      - The concept of Directors was informal and referred to anyone
      willing to lend a hand which included over 20 individuals, possibly more
      - I was never involved with fund collection; money went to you
      - I was never involved with any disbursements; It was paid by you
      - I was not a signer on the bank account but was only given read-only
      access to the bank app
      - I was not involved with contracts or sponsorship agreements outside
      trying to draft example language that could *potentially* be used
      - The 1-2 occurrences where I generated receipts was exclusively at
      your direction

I cannot and will not assist in anything outside my knowledge or duty.



//adam

*Adam Peacock*


On Wed, Oct 1, 2025 at 9:10 AM Charles A <caambrosecchia@gmail.com> wrote:

> Unreal but it’s likely a setup. You need to reject the notion that you had
> any title, especially accounting or finance. Cite the fact that you were
> never in the know of accounting irregularities, lack of
> contracts/agreements for sponsorship payments, ever changing receipts for

instruction: Write a professional email to: tgore@yahoo.com
input: Subject: Re: CARS Final Appeal
output:
Hello Tom,

I understand you may be seeking closure but here are some things to keep in
mind:

   - The Texas SOS always had the same 3 officers/directors as when you
   first created the charity organization: Tom G, JJ and Yasser
   - I never held any official title with regard to anything
   financial-related or otherwise and the TX SOS will confirm; the last known
   individual who accepted the role of Treasurer/CFO was Tom Baird
   - The concept of Directors was informal and referred to anyone willing
   to lend a hand which included over 20 individuals, possibly more
   - I was never involved with fund collection; money went to you
   - I was never involved with any disbursements; It was paid by you
   - I was not a signer on the bank account but was only given read-only
   access to the bank app
   - I was not involved with contracts or sponsorship agreements outside
   trying to draft example language that could *potentially* be used
   - The 1-2 occurrences where I generated receipts was exclusively at your
   direction

I cannot and will not assist in anything outside my knowledge or duty.

*Adam Peacock*

Goods/Services. Please review it and let us know of any elements that you
are no longer offering as they will need to be deleted. We need to delete
anything that you are no longer offering because the USPTO can choose a
Registration at random for an audit to see if the Trademark Registration is
accurate with current offerings. If you are found to not be accurate during
an audit, the USPTO will penalize you ($250!) and we do not want that to
happen. *Also note that the mandatory USPTO Filing Fees for each Class that
you decide to keep are $**650**.*

field of employee recruitment and short term placement



*Remove this:*#Class 42: Consultation services in the field of information
technology, software development and hosting the websites of others overseas


*3. Use in Commerce* - In order to prepare your Renewal filing, we need to
show proof of continuous use of the exact Mark  'AQORN' in relation to *EACH
CLASS*, as listed above. Can you please show/explain to us where the
general public can avail your services? For example: website links, photos
of a physical business’ signage, brochures, fliers, previous invoices,
business cards, etc..

> Role: *Sr. OpenStack Engineer*
>
> *Position: Contract*
>
> *Location: San Jose CA (Remote)*
>
>
>
> Job Description
>
>
>
> *Key Responsibilities:*
>
> Design and deploy OpenStack cloud infrastructure.
>
> Configure and manage OpenStack components (Nova, Neutron, Cinder, Swift,
> etc.).
>
> Monitor system performance and troubleshoot issues.
>
> Collaborate with cross-functional teams (DevOps, Security, Networking).
>
> Develop automation scripts using tools like Ansible, Chef, or Puppet.
>
> Maintain technical documentation and support Tier III customer issues.
>
> Evaluate and integrate new technologies to improve cloud efficiency.
>
> Ensure compliance with security standards and best practices.
>
> Required Skills:
>
> Deep understanding of OpenStack architecture and components.
>
> Strong Linux system administration skills.
>
> Proficiency in scripting languages (Python, Bash, Ruby, Go).
>
> Experience with virtualization platforms (KVM, Xen).
>
> Familiarity with networking concepts (IP subnetting, load balancing,
> firewalls).
>
> Knowledge of CI/CD pipelines and DevOps practices.
>
> Experience with Infrastructure as Code (Terraform, Ansible).
>
> Version control systems (Git).
>
> RESTful API development and integration.
>
> Qualifications:
>
> Bachelor’s degree in Computer Science, IT, or related field.
>
> 5+ years of experience in cloud computing or OpenStack development.
>
> Experience with public cloud platforms (AWS, Azure, GCP) is a plus.
>
> Certified OpenStack Administrator (COA) is advantageous.

On Wed, Sep 17, 2025 at 12:15 PM Nikhil Tyagi <Ntyagi@xchangesoft.net>
wrote:

> Role: *Sr. OpenStack Engineer*
>
> *Position: Contract*
>
> *Location: San Jose CA (Remote)*
>
>
>
> Job Description
>
>
>
> *Key Responsibilities:*
>
> Design and deploy OpenStack cloud infrastructure.
>
> Configure and manage OpenStack components (Nova, Neutron, Cinder, Swift,
> etc.).
>
> Monitor system performance and troubleshoot issues.
>
> Collaborate with cross-functional teams (DevOps, Security, Networking).
>
> Develop automation scripts using tools like Ansible, Chef, or Puppet.
>
> Maintain technical documentation and support Tier III customer issues.
>
> Evaluate and integrate new technologies to improve cloud efficiency.
>
> Ensure compliance with security standards and best practices.
>
> Required Skills:
>
> Deep understanding of OpenStack architecture and components.
>
> Strong Linux system administration skills.
>
> Proficiency in scripting languages (Python, Bash, Ruby, Go).
>
> Experience with virtualization platforms (KVM, Xen).
>
> Familiarity with networking concepts (IP subnetting, load balancing,
> firewalls).
>
> Knowledge of CI/CD pipelines and DevOps practices.
>
> Experience with Infrastructure as Code (Terraform, Ansible).
>
> Version control systems (Git).
>
> RESTful API development and integration.
>
> Qualifications:
>
> Bachelor’s degree in Computer Science, IT, or related field.
>
> 5+ years of experience in cloud computing or OpenStack development.
>
> Experience with public cloud platforms (AWS, Azure, GCP) is a plus.
>
> Certified OpenStack Administrator (COA) is advantageous.
>
>

>
>
>
> *Senior OpenStack DevOps Engineer*
> *California Based Client*
> *remote*
> *work hours- 7.00am-4.00pm PST*
> *Core skills:*
> -8-9+ years of experience operating and automating large-scale OpenStack
> cloud environments, preferably in community-driven or upstream-contributing
> teams
> -Expert-level proficiency in Infrastructure-as-Code with Ansible,
> Terraform, or Pulumi
> -Strong hands-on knowledge of Neutron, Octavia, Manila, Cinder, Nova,
> Ironic, and Glance
> -Strong Linux (RHEL/CentOS/Ubuntu) systems engineering background with
> advanced scripting in Python, Bash, or Go
> -Fluency with Git, CI/CD pipelines, and automated test frameworks
> -Strong understanding of L2/L3 networking, SDN overlays (VXLAN, Geneve),
> load balancing (Octavia), and storage protocols (SDS) (iSCSI, NFS, CEPH)
> -Demonstrated success building or maintaining multi-region or
> high-availability OpenStack clusters
> -Experience with container technologies (e.g., Docker) and orchestration
> tools (e.g., Kubernetes) is a plus
> -Ability to write technical documentation and contribute to community
> wikis or knowledge bases
> *Preferred Qualifications:*
> Contributions to upstream OpenStack codebases or participation in SIGs/WGs
> Familiarity with RBAC, Keystone federation, Barbican (secrets management),
> and Ceilometer/Gnocchi/Aodh
> Understanding of security best practices for tenant isolation,
> microsegmentation, and compliance (e.g., CIS, NIST)
> Background in telco, edge cloud, or large enterprise infrastructure
> environments
> Experience building and maintaining automated test environments
> for OpenStack upgrades and validation (e.g., Tempest, Rally, or custom test
> harnesses)
> Bachelor’s degree in computer science, IT, Engineering, or a related field
> preferred; equivalent experience and relevant industry certifications will
> also be considered
> *Key Responsibilities:*
> Design and implement multi-tenant OpenStack infrastructure aligned
> with open community standards, including network service isolation and
> tenant-aware resource scheduling
> Automate the provisioning, lifecycle management, and configuration
> of OpenStack services and supporting components using Ansible, Terraform,
> or Pulumi
> Extend and maintain integrations for core OpenStack services:
> Neutron: Custom network plugins/drivers, L2/L3 routing, BGP, DHCP, and
> tenant network segmentation (VLAN, VXLAN, Geneve).
> Octavia: HA load balancing with amphora and provider drivers, TLS
> offloading, Layer 4/7 routing.
> Manila: Share drivers for NFS/CIFS, tenant access control, storage
> backends.
> Cinder: Block storage provisioning, volume snapshots, multi-attach,
> backend tuning.
> Nova: Compute resource scheduling, NUMA/cpu pinning, SR-IOV and PCI
> passthrough.
> Ironic: Bare metal provisioning workflows, BIOS/IPMI automation, PXE and
> UEFI boot configuration.
> Glance: Image lifecycle management, backing store optimization, image
> caching strategies
> Contribute to upstream OpenStack projects when needed (bug fixes, driver
> enhancements, documentation)
> Implement continuous delivery pipelines for OpenStack updates, including
> patch management, service upgrade testing, and rollback procedures
> Develop automated monitoring, alerting, and healing mechanisms using
> GitOps principles and observability stacks (e.g., Prometheus, Loki, Grafana)
> Harden services for high availability, disaster recovery, and scale-out
> operations
> Perform deep-dive troubleshooting and performance analysis of OpenStack
> services across control and data planes
> Participate in on-call rotation, in

>>

>> substance of the refusal.  We'd just be taking a side exit by going on the
>> Supplemental Register.
>>
>> Thanks,
>>
>> Trevor
>>
>>

>> in next steps given descriptive words is difficult to combat.
>>
>> //adam

>>

>> trevoracaudleesq@mytclpoahuboa.com> wrote:
>>
>>> Hello again Adam,
>>>
>>> Thank you for reaching back out to me.  I reviewed the entire
>>> prosecution history of your trademark and I may be able to help you out.
>>> The biggest issue (but not necessarily the only issue) is that the USPTO
>>> has argued that your Mark is "merely descriptive". Now, it is entirely
>>> possible to respond and argue that your Mark is NOT descriptive...but that
>>> can be an expensive argument to make, and in most cases, not an argument
>>> that will win. You may wish to pursue that path, but if that is your
>>> decision, then I will not be able to help.
>>>
>>> If, on the other hand, you are willing to concede their argument with
>>> respect to descriptiveness, then you can amend your application to the
>>> "Supplemental Register" (as opposed to the "Principal Register"), and your
>>> application should proceed to registration, barring any other major issues
>>> that arise. You can learn more about the pros and cons of the Supplemental
>>> Register at this link:
>>> https://www.nolo.com/legal-encyclopedia/what-good-the-supplemental-register.html
>>>
>>> IMPORTANT!!! - Note that Amazon.com WILL NOT accept you into their brand
>>> registry program with a Supplemental Register registration!!!
>>>
>>> If the above sounds like it would work for you, I would charge you a
>>> $285 Attorney’s Fee.
>>>
>>> If this is something that you are interested in, please let me know and
>>> we'll get you signed up.
>>>
>>> Thank you,
>>>
>>> Trevor
>>>
>>> PS - You can verify my credentials with the California State Bar here:
>>> http://members.calbar.ca.gov/fal/Licensee/Detail/232294
>>>
>>>
>>>
>>>  *Client pays USPTO Filing Fees, if any. Any

input: Subject: Re: query udpate
output:
def submit_search(session, query, host, job_conf):
    """
    Create a Splunk search job with safe defaults.
    - Prepends 'search ' if SPL doesn't start with a generating command
    - Reads optional search_mode from job_conf[QUERY]
    - Falls back gracefully if server rejects search_mode
    """
    q = query.strip()
    if not q.lower().startswith(('search', '|', 'tstats', 'inputlookup',
'metadata', 'from')):
        q = 'search ' + q

    url = f"{host}/services/search/jobs"

    # optional search_mode from job_conf
    wanted_mode = None
    if 'QUERY' in job_conf and 'search_mode' in job_conf['QUERY']:
        wanted_mode = job_conf['QUERY'].get('search_mode', '').lower()
    allowed_modes = {'fast', 'smart', 'verbose'}
    use_mode = wanted_mode if wanted_mode in allowed_modes else None

    data = {
        'search': q,
        'output_mode': 'json',
        'exec_mode': 'normal',
        'status_buckets': 0
    }
    if use_mode:
        data['search_mode'] = use_mode

    # submit
    r = splunk_request(session, 'POST', url, data=data)
    if r.status_code == 201:
        return r.json()['sid']

    # fallback: retry without search_mode if invalid
    err_text = (r.text or "").lower()
    if ('invalid search mode' in err_text or 'search_mode' in err_text) and
'search_mode' in data:
        data.pop('search_mode', None)
        r = splunk_request(session, 'POST', url, data=data)
        if r.status_code == 201:
            return r.json()['sid']

    print("\n[submit_search] Error creating job")
    print(f"URL: {url}")
    print(f"Payload: {data}")
    print(f"Status: {r.status_code}")
    print(f"Response: {r.text}")
    r.raise_for_status()

instruction: Write a professional email to: adam.peacock@transunion.com
input: Subject: query udpate
output:
1.

   insert_results_mysql (handles empty results, sanitizes columns, adds
   created_at timestamp)
   2.

   The *entire main block* (checks resultCount, writes even when 0, then
   normalizes/filters and inserts)

------------------------------
insert_results_mysql (full function)

def _sanitize_col(name: str) -> str:
    """Sanitize a key into a safe MySQL column name."""
    s = ''.join(ch if (ch.isalnum() or ch == '_') else '_' for ch in
str(name).strip())
    if not s:
        s = 'col'
    if s[0].isdigit():
        s = '_' + s
    return s
def insert_results_mysql(results, static_mysql_conf, dynamic_mysql_conf):
    """
    Create/extend the table to fit `results` and insert rows.
    - Sanitizes column names consistently for CREATE + INSERT
    - Adds missing columns if table already exists
    - Appends `created_at` (UTC) to every row
    - If `results` is empty, inserts a placeholder row
(feature=NO_DATA, count=0)
    """
    import pymysql
    import datetime

    conn = pymysql.connect(
        host=static_mysql_conf['host'],
        user=static_mysql_conf['user'],
        password=static_mysql_conf['password'],
        database=dynamic_mysql_conf['database']
    )
    cursor = conn.cursor()
    table = dynamic_mysql_conf['table']

    now_utc = datetime.datetime.utcnow()

    # ---------- Case 1: no results → ensure minimal schema + insert
placeholder ----------
    if not results:
        create_stmt = f"""
        CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS `{table}` (
            id INT AUTO_INCREMENT PRIMARY KEY,
            `feature` TEXT,
            `count` BIGINT,
            `created_at` DATETIME DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP
        )
        """
        cursor.execute(create_stmt)

        # Ensure columns exist if table pre-exists
        cursor.execute(f"SHOW COLUMNS FROM `{table}`")
        existing = {row[0] for row in cursor.fetchall()}
        if "feature" not in existing:
            cursor.execute(f"ALTER TABLE `{table}` ADD COLUMN `feature` TEXT")
        if "count" not in existing:
            cursor.execute(f"ALTER TABLE `{table}` ADD COLUMN `count` BIGINT")
        if "created_at" not in existing:
            cursor.execute(f"ALTER TABLE `{table}` ADD COLUMN
`created_at` DATETIME DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP")

        cursor.execute(
            f"INSERT INTO `{table}` (`feature`,`count`,`created_at`)
VALUES (%s,%s,%s)",
            ("NO_DATA", 0, now_utc)
        )
        conn.commit()
        cursor.close(); conn.close()
        return

    # ---------- Case 2: have results → dynamic schema with
sanitization ----------
    # 1) stable list of original keys
    all_keys = set()
    for r in results:
        all_keys.update(r.keys())
    orig_keys = sorted(all_keys)  # deterministic order

    # 2) map originals -> sanitized (handle collisions)
    orig_to_san = {}
    used = set()
    for k in orig_keys:
        base = _sanitize_col(k)
        col = base
        i = 2
        while col in used:
            col = f"{base}_{i}"
            i += 1
        used.add(col)
        orig_to_san[k] = col

    # 3) ensure table exists with needed columns + created_at
    col_defs = ", ".join(f"`{orig_to_san[k]}` TEXT" for k in orig_keys)
    create_stmt = f"""
    CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS `{table}` (
        id INT AUTO_INCREMENT PRIMARY KEY,
        {col_defs},
        `created_at` DATETIME DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP
    )
    """
    cursor.execute(create_stmt)

    # 4) add any missing columns (table may pre-exist)
    cursor.execute(f"SHOW COLUMNS FROM `{table}`")
    existing = {row[0] for row in cursor.fetchall()}
    for k in orig_keys:
        san = orig_to_san[k]
        if san not in existing:
            try:
                cursor.execute(f"ALTER TABLE `{table}` ADD COLUMN `{san}` TEXT")
            except Exception:
                pass
    if "created_at" not in existing:
        try:

-

   Builds a *stable list of original keys* (sorted for deterministic order)
   -

   Maps each original key → a *sanitized* MySQL column name (same map used
   for CREATE and INSERT)
   -

   *Adds missing columns* if the table already exists (so repeated runs
   don’t break)
   -

   Inserts row values in the *same original-key order*

def _sanitize_col(name: str) -> str:
    s = ''.join(ch if (ch.isalnum() or ch == '_') else '_' for ch in
str(name).strip())
    if not s:
        s = 'col'
    if s[0].isdigit():
        s = '_' + s
    return s
def insert_results_mysql(results, static_mysql_conf, dynamic_mysql_conf):
    import pymysql
    conn = pymysql.connect(
        host=static_mysql_conf['host'],
        user=static_mysql_conf['user'],
        password=static_mysql_conf['password'],
        database=dynamic_mysql_conf['database']
    )
    cursor = conn.cursor()
    table = dynamic_mysql_conf['table']

    if not results:
        cursor.close(); conn.close()
        return

    # 1) Union of original keys (deterministic order)
    all_keys = set()
    for r in results:
        all_keys.update(r.keys())
    orig_keys = sorted(all_keys)  # <— stable order across CREATE and INSERT

    # 2) Map originals -> sanitized, with collision handling
    orig_to_san = {}
    used = set()
    for k in orig_keys:
        base = _sanitize_col(k)
        col = base
        i = 2
        while col in used:
            col = f"{base}_{i}"
            i += 1
        used.add(col)
        orig_to_san[k] = col

    # 3) Ensure table exists with all needed columns
    col_defs = ", ".join(f"`{orig_to_san[k]}` TEXT" for k in orig_keys)
    create_stmt = f"""
    CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS `{table}` (
        id INT AUTO_INCREMENT PRIMARY KEY,
        {col_defs}
    )
    """
    cursor.execute(create_stmt)

    # 4) If table pre-existed, add any missing columns
    cursor.execute(f"SHOW COLUMNS FROM `{table}`")
    existing = {row[0] for row in cursor.fetchall()}
    for k in orig_keys:
        san = orig_to_san[k]
        if san not in existing:
            try:
                cursor.execute(f"ALTER TABLE `{table}` ADD COLUMN `{san}` TEXT")
            except Exception:
                # ignore duplicates or races
                pass

    # 5) INSERT using sanitized column names, values in orig_keys order
    san_cols_order = [orig_to_san[k] for k in orig_keys]
    col_list = ", ".join(f"`{c}`" for c in san_cols_order)
    placeholders = ", ".join(["%s"] * len(orig_keys))
    insert_stmt = f"INSERT INTO `{table}` ({col_list}) VALUES ({placeholders})"

    # (Optional) print once to verify mapping:
    # print("Column mapping:", orig_to_san)

    for r in results:
        values = [str(r.get(k, "")) for k in orig_keys]
        cursor.execute(insert_stmt, values)

    conn.commit()
    cursor.close(); conn.close()

Why this fixes “unknown column 'feature'”

   -

   If your normalized rows include feature, then orig_keys contains
   "feature".
   -

   The function *creates/ensures* a column for it (feature → sanitized,
   which stays feature since it’s safe).
   -

   The INSERT targets that sanitized name, not the raw/original when they
   differ.
   -

   If the table already exists from a prior run without feature, step 4 *adds
   it* before inserting.

If you still see the error

   -

   Confirm you’re writing to the intended *database/schema* (
   dynamic_mysql_conf['database']) and the right *table*.
   -

   Run DESCRIBE your_table; and check whether feature (or its sanitized
   form) exists.
   -

   Add the debug print("Column mapping:", orig_to_san) once to verify which
   columns it’s creating

def _sanitize_col(name: str) -> str:
    """Sanitize a key into a safe MySQL column name."""
    s = ''.join(ch if (ch.isalnum() or ch == '_') else '_' for ch in
str(name).strip())
    if not s:
        s = 'col'
    if s[0].isdigit():
        s = '_' + s
    return s

def insert_results_mysql(results, static_mysql_conf, dynamic_mysql_conf):
    """
    Create/extend the table to fit `results` and insert all rows.
    - Sanitizes column names consistently for CREATE + INSERT
    - Adds missing columns if table already exists
    - Appends `created_at` (UTC) to every row
    """
    import pymysql
    import datetime

    conn = pymysql.connect(
        host=static_mysql_conf['host'],
        user=static_mysql_conf['user'],
        password=static_mysql_conf['password'],
        database=dynamic_mysql_conf['database']
    )
    cursor = conn.cursor()
    table = dynamic_mysql_conf['table']

    if not results:
        cursor.close(); conn.close()
        return

    # 1) Stable list of original keys across all rows
    all_keys = set()
    for r in results:
        all_keys.update(r.keys())
    orig_keys = sorted(all_keys)  # deterministic order

    # 2) Map originals -> sanitized (with collision handling)
    orig_to_san = {}
    used = set()
    for k in orig_keys:
        base = _sanitize_col(k)
        col = base
        i = 2
        while col in used:
            col = f"{base}_{i}"
            i += 1
        used.add(col)
        orig_to_san[k] = col

    # 3) Ensure table exists with all needed columns + created_at
    col_defs = ", ".join(f"`{orig_to_san[k]}` TEXT" for k in orig_keys)
    create_stmt = f"""
    CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS `{table}` (
        id INT AUTO_INCREMENT PRIMARY KEY,
        {col_defs},
        created_at DATETIME DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP
    )
    """
    cursor.execute(create_stmt)

    # 4) If table pre-existed, add any missing columns
    cursor.execute(f"SHOW COLUMNS FROM `{table}`")
    existing = {row[0] for row in cursor.fetchall()}

    # Add data columns
    for k in orig_keys:
        san = orig_to_san[k]
        if san not in existing:
            try:
                cursor.execute(f"ALTER TABLE `{table}` ADD COLUMN `{san}`
TEXT")
            except Exception:
                # ignore duplicates/races
                pass

    # Ensure created_at exists
    if "created_at" not in existing:
        try:
            cursor.execute(f"ALTER TABLE `{table}` ADD COLUMN `created_at`
DATETIME DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP")
        except Exception:
            pass

    # 5) INSERT rows using sanitized columns + created_at
    san_cols_order = [orig_to_san[k] for k in orig_keys]
    col_list = ", ".join(f"`{c}`" for c in san_cols_order) + ",
`created_at`"
    placeholders = ", ".join(["%s"] * len(orig_keys)) + ", %s"
    insert_stmt = f"INSERT INTO `{table}` ({col_list}) VALUES
({placeholders})"

    now_utc = datetime.datetime.utcnow()
    for r in results:
        values = [str(r.get(k, "")) for k in orig_keys]
        values.append(now_utc)  # per-row timestamp; change to
datetime.datetime.utcnow() inside loop if you want unique nanos
        cursor.execute(insert_stmt, values)

    conn.commit()
    cursor.close(); conn.close()

import os, time, sys, argparse, configparser, datetime, urllib3
import json, requests, pymysql

# Disable SSL warnings (use only in dev/test)
urllib3.disable_warnings(urllib3.exceptions.InsecureRequestWarning)

# === CONFIG LOADING ===

def load_ini_config(file_path):
    config = configparser.ConfigParser()
    config.read(file_path)
    return config

# === SPLUNK FUNCTIONS ===

def get_splunk_session(splunk_conf):
    session = requests.Session()
    session.auth = (splunk_conf['username'], splunk_conf['password'])
    session.verify = False  # Only for self-signed certs in dev/test
    return session

def submit_search(session, query, host):
    url = f"{host}/services/search/jobs"
    data = {'search': query, 'output_mode': 'json'}
    response = session.post(url, data=data)
    response.raise_for_status()
    return response.json()['sid']

def wait_for_completion(session, host, sid):
    url = f"{host}/services/search/jobs/{sid}"
    start_time = datetime.datetime.now()
    spinner = ['|', '/', '-', '\\']
    spin_idx = 0

    while True:
        response = session.get(url, params={'output_mode': 'json'})
        content = response.json()['entry'][0]['content']

        is_done = content['isDone']
        percent = content.get('doneProgress', 0) * 100
        scanned = content.get('scanCount', '?')
        event_count = content.get('eventCount', '?')
        result_count = content.get('resultCount', '?')
        elapsed = datetime.datetime.now() - start_time

        sys.stdout.write(
            f"\r[{spinner[spin_idx % 4]}] "
            f"Progress: {percent:.1f}% | Scanned: {scanned} | "
            f"Matched: {event_count} | Results: {result_count} | Elapsed:
{str(elapsed).split('.')[0]}  "
        )
        sys.stdout.flush()
        spin_idx += 1

        if is_done:
            print("\n Search complete.")
            break
        time.sleep(2)

def get_results(session, host, sid):
    results = []
    offset = 0
    count = 1 #50000
    while True:
        url = f"{host}/services/search/jobs/{sid}/results"
        params = {'output_mode': 'json', 'count': count, 'offset': offset}
        response = session.get(url, params=params)
        response.raise_for_status()
        chunk = response.json()['results']
        if not chunk:
            break
        results.extend(chunk)
        offset += len(chunk)
    return results


# === NORMALIZATION / FILTERING (today's update) ===

from typing import Any, Dict, List, Optional, Tuple
Row = Dict[str, Any]

def detect_keys(rows: List[Row]) -> Tuple[Optional[str], Optional[str]]:
    """Heuristically find feature/count keys from the first row."""
    if not rows:
        return None, None
    sample = rows[0]
    keys = list(sample.keys())
    count_key = next((k for k in keys if k.lower() in
('count','total','value','n')), None)
    feature_key = next((k for k in keys if k != count_key), None)
    return feature_key, count_key

def normalize_reply(reply: Any,
                    feature_key: Optional[str] = None,
                    count_key: Optional[str] = None) -> List[Row]:
    """
    Accepts list-of-dicts or single dict; returns list with added
'feature'/'count' keys
    (leaving original fields intact). Coerces count to int if possible.
    """
    if isinstance(reply, dict):
        rows = [reply]
    elif isinstance(reply, list) and all(isinstance(x, dict) for x in
reply):
        rows = reply
    else:
        return []

    if not feature_key or not count_key:
        fk, ck = detect_keys(rows)
        feature_key = feature_key or fk
        count_key   = count_key or ck

    out: List[Row] = []
    for r in rows:
        nr = dict(r)
        # feature
        feat = r.get(feature_key) if feature_key else None
        if feat is not None:
            nr['feature'] = str(feat).strip()
        # count
        cnt = r.get(count_key) if count

        response = session.get(url, params={'output_mode': 'json'})
        content = response.json()['entry'][0]['content']

        is_done = content['isDone']
        percent = content.get('doneProgress', 0) * 100
        scanned = content.get('scanCount', '?')
        event_count = content.get('eventCount', '?')
        result_count = content.get('resultCount', '?')
        elapsed = datetime.datetime.now() - start_time

        sys.stdout.write(
            f"\r[{spinner[spin_idx % 4]}] "
            f"Progress: {percent:.1f}% | Scanned: {scanned} | "
            f"Matched: {event_count} | Results: {result_count} | Elapsed:
{str(elapsed).split('.')[0]}  "
        )
        sys.stdout.flush()
        spin_idx += 1

            print("\n Search complete.")
            break
        time.sleep(2)

def get_results(session, host, sid):
    results = []
    offset = 0
    count = 1 #50000

        url = f"{host}/services/search/jobs/{sid}/results"
        params = {'output_mode': 'json', 'count': count, 'offset': offset}
        response = session.get(url, params=params)
        response.raise_for_status()
        chunk = response.json()['results']
        if not chunk:
            break
        results.extend(chunk)
        offset += len(chunk)
    return results

# === MYSQL FUNCTIONS ===

def insert_results_mysql(results, static_mysql_conf, dynamic_mysql_conf):
    conn = pymysql.connect(
        host=static_mysql_conf['host'],
        user=static_mysql_conf['user'],
        password=static_mysql_conf['password'],

    )
    cursor = conn.cursor()

    if results:
        keys = results[0].keys()
        create_stmt = f"""
        CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS {table} (
            id INT AUTO_INCREMENT PRIMARY KEY,

        )
        """
        cursor.execute(create_stmt)

            cols = ', '.join(row.keys())
            placeholders = ', '.join(['%s'] * len(row))
            values = [str(v) for v in row.values()]
            insert_stmt = f"INSERT INTO {table} ({cols}) VALUES
({placeholders})"
            cursor.execute(insert_stmt, values)

# === MAIN SCRIPT ===

instruction: Write a professional email to: adam.peacock@transunion.com
input: Subject: error2
output:
1) *Add a few imports*

At the top (with the other imports), add typing helpers:

from typing import Any, Dict, List, Optional

------------------------------
2) *Insert normalization + filtering helpers*

Paste the block *right above* the # === MYSQL FUNCTIONS === line (i.e.,
after get_results(...)):

# === RESULT NORMALIZATION / FILTERING ===

Row = Dict[str, Any]
def detect_keys(rows: List[Row]) -> (Optional[str], Optional[str]):
    """Heuristically find feature/count keys from the first row."""
    if not rows:
        return None, None
    sample = rows[0]
    keys = list(sample.keys())
    # count key: common names
    count_key = next((k for k in keys if k.lower() in
('count','total','value','n')), None)
    # feature key: first non-count key
    feature_key = next((k for k in keys if k != count_key), None)
    return feature_key, count_key
def normalize_reply(reply: Any,
                    feature_key: Optional[str] = None,
                    count_key: Optional[str] = None) -> List[Row]:
    """Accepts list-of-dicts or a single dict; returns list of dicts
with 'feature'/'count' added."""
    # unify to list of dicts
    if isinstance(reply, dict):
        rows = [reply]
    elif isinstance(reply, list) and all(isinstance(x, dict) for x in reply):
        rows = reply
    else:
        return []

    # auto-detect keys if not provided
    if not feature_key or not count_key:
        fk, ck = detect_keys(rows)
        feature_key = feature_key or fk
        count_key   = count_key or ck

    out: List[Row] = []
    for r in rows:
        # keep original fields
        nr = dict(r)

        # feature
        feat = r.get(feature_key) if feature_key else None
        if feat is not None:
            nr['feature'] = str(feat).strip()

        # count (coerce to int if present)
        cnt = r.get(count_key) if count_key else None
        if cnt is not None:
            try:
                nr['count'] = int(str(cnt).replace(',', ''))
            except Exception:
                try:
                    nr['count'] = int(float(str(cnt).replace(',', '')))
                except Exception:
                    nr['count'] = 0

        out.append(nr)
    return out
def filter_features(rows: List[Row],
                    include_one: Optional[str] = None) -> List[Row]:
    """If include_one is set, keep only rows whose 'feature' equals
that name (case-insensitive)."""
    if not include_one:
        return rows
    needle = include_one.lower().strip()
    kept: List[Row] = []
    for r in rows:
        name = str(r.get('feature', '')).lower().strip()
        if name == needle:
            kept.append(r)
    return kept

------------------------------
3) *Read optional overrides from your INI (feature/count names, category to
isolate)*

In your *main script block*, *right after* you read the query:

    splunk_query = job_conf['QUERY']['search']

add:

    # Optional per-job overrides (safe if absent)
    feature_key = job_conf['QUERY'].get('feature_key', fallback=None)
    count_key   = job_conf['QUERY'].get('count_key', fallback=None)
    include_feature = job_conf['QUERY'].get('include_feature',
fallback=None)  # isolate one category if set

You’ll now be able to put in your job INI:

[QUERY]search = index=_internal | stats count by sourcetypefeature_key
= sourcetypecount_key = countinclude_feature = WAF

------------------------------
4) *Normalize (and optionally filter) before inserting into MySQL*

Still in the *main* block, *replace* this portion:

    results = get_results(session, splunk_conf['host'], sid)
    print(f"\nFetched {len(results)} results.")

    # Insert into MySQL
    insert_results_mysql(results, static_mysql_conf, dynamic_mysql_conf)

*with this:*

    results = get_results(session, splunk_conf['host'], sid)
    print(f"\nFetched {len(results)} results.")

    # Normalize field nam

instruction: Write a professional email to: adam.peacock@transunion.com
input: Subject: Re: updated
output:
CREATE TABLE is failing because one of the column names is *empty/invalid*,
and count is also a SQL function (needs quoting). You’re building columns
directly from result keys without sanitizing or quoting, so MySQL sees:

... ,  TEXT, count TEXT, feature TEXT )
       ^ empty name   ^ reserved word (needs backticks)

Fix (minimal patch)

   1.

   *Add a small sanitizer* (top-level, near your MySQL helpers):

def _sanitize_col(name: str) -> str:
    """Make a safe MySQL column name: letters/digits/underscore;
others -> underscore."""
    s = ''.join(ch if (ch.isalnum() or ch == '_') else '_' for ch in str(name))
    if not s:
        s = 'col'
    if s[0].isdigit():
        s = '_' + s
    return s


   2.

   *Replace your insert_results_mysql* with this version that:


   -

   Drops empty keys
   -

   Sanitizes names
   -

   Uses backticks for every column
   -

   Keeps column order stable

def insert_results_mysql(results, static_mysql_conf, dynamic_mysql_conf):
    conn = pymysql.connect(
        host=static_mysql_conf['host'],
        user=static_mysql_conf['user'],
        password=static_mysql_conf['password'],
        database=dynamic_mysql_conf['database']
    )
    cursor = conn.cursor()
    table = dynamic_mysql_conf['table']

    if results:
        # Collect all keys across rows; drop empty/None keys
        all_keys = []
        seen = set()
        for r in results:
            for k in r.keys():
                if not k:
                    continue
                if k not in seen:
                    all_keys.append(k)
                    seen.add(k)

        # Map original -> sanitized, ensuring uniqueness
        col_map = {}
        used = set()
        for k in all_keys:
            san = _sanitize_col(k)
            # avoid collisions (e.g., two different keys both sanitize
to same name)
            base, i = san, 2
            while san in used:
                san = f"{base}_{i}"
                i += 1
            col_map[k] = san
            used.add(san)

        # Build CREATE TABLE
        col_defs = ", ".join(f"`{san}` TEXT" for san in col_map.values())
        create_stmt = f"""
        CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS `{table}` (
            id INT AUTO_INCREMENT PRIMARY KEY,
            {col_defs}
        )
        """
        cursor.execute(create_stmt)

        # Build INSERT
        col_list = ", ".join(f"`{san}`" for san in col_map.values())
        placeholders = ", ".join(["%s"] * len(col_map))
        insert_stmt = f"INSERT INTO `{table}` ({col_list}) VALUES
({placeholders})"

        # Insert rows
        for r in results:
            values = [str(r.get(orig, "")) for orig in col_map.keys()]
            cursor.execute(insert_stmt, values)

        conn.commit()

    cursor.close()
    conn.close()


*Adam Peacock*

Principal Architect
Office: +1-214-810-5701

instruction: Write a professional email to: adam.peacock@transunion.com
input: Subject: Re: error2
output:
updated cocde:

#!/usr/bin/env python3
# -*- coding: utf-8 -*-
"""
Splunk → MySQL exporter (updated)

Features
- Static splunk.ini for Splunk + MySQL credentials
- Per-job job.ini for: query, database, table, optional search_mode,
count_only,
  feature_key, count_key, include_feature
- Splunk sessionKey auth with auto re-login on 401
- submit_search with safe fast-like defaults (no 'rf' at job creation)
- wait_for_completion that never cancels after timeout; logs queue
diagnostics
- results pagination
- count_only path: store resultCount + Splunk dispatchTime
- normalization: auto-detect or override feature/count keys; optional
single-feature filter
"""

import sys
import os
import time
import json
import argparse
import configparser
import urllib3
import requests
import pymysql
import xml.etree.ElementTree as ET
from datetime import datetime
from typing import Any, Dict, List, Optional, Tuple

urllib3.disable_warnings(urllib3.exceptions.InsecureRequestWarning)

Row = Dict[str, Any]

# =========================
# Config helpers
# =========================

def load_ini_config(file_path: str) -> configparser.ConfigParser:
    cfg = configparser.ConfigParser()
    with open(file_path, 'r') as f:
        cfg.read_file(f)
    return cfg

# =========================
# Splunk auth & HTTP helpers
# =========================

def splunk_login(session: requests.Session, host: str, username: str,
password: str) -> None:
    """Obtain a Splunk sessionKey and set it on the session headers."""
    url = f"{host}/services/auth/login"
    r = session.post(url, data={'username': username, 'password':
password}, verify=session.verify)
    r.raise_for_status()
    try:
        key = ET.fromstring(r.text).findtext('.//sessionKey')
    except Exception:
        key = None
    if not key:
        raise RuntimeError("Failed to obtain Splunk sessionKey (bad creds
or endpoint)")
    session.headers.update({'Authorization': f'Splunk {key}'})
    session.auth = None  # don't mix methods

def get_splunk_session(splunk_conf: configparser.SectionProxy) ->
requests.Session:
    session = requests.Session()
    # For dev/self-signed certs set verify False; in prod, provide a CA
bundle or cert path.
    session.verify = False
    session._splunk_host = splunk_conf['host']
    session._splunk_user = splunk_conf['username']
    session._splunk_pass = splunk_conf['password']
    splunk_login(session, splunk_conf['host'], splunk_conf['username'],
splunk_conf['password'])
    return session

def splunk_request(session: requests.Session, method: str, url: str,
**kwargs) -> requests.Response:
    """
    Wrapper that retries once on 401 by re-login.
    Expects _splunk_host/_splunk_user/_splunk_pass set on session.
    """
    r = session.request(method, url, **kwargs)
    if r.status_code == 401:
        splunk_login(session, session._splunk_host, session._splunk_user,
session._splunk_pass)
        r = session.request(method, url, **kwargs)
    r.raise_for_status()
    return r

# =========================
# Splunk search lifecycle
# =========================

def submit_search(session: requests.Session, query: str, host: str,
job_conf: configparser.ConfigParser) -> str:
    """
    Create a Splunk search job with safe defaults.
    - Prepends 'search ' if SPL doesn't start with a generating command
    - Tries search_mode (fast/smart/verbose) if provided; retries without
if server rejects
    - Avoids unsupported params at job creation (e.g., rf)
    """
    q = query.strip()
    if not q.lower().startswith(('search', '|', 'tstats', 'inputlookup',
'metadata', 'from')):
        q = 'search ' + q

    url = f"{host}/services/search/jobs"

    wanted_mode = job_conf['QUERY'].get('search_mode', 'fast').lower() if
'QUERY' in job_conf else 'fast'
    allowed_modes = {'fast', 'smart', 'verbose'}
    use_mode = wanted_mode if wanted_mode in allowed_mode

instruction: Write a professional email to: adam.peacock@transunion.com
input: Subject: Re:
output:
def wait_for_completion(session, host, sid, queue_timeout_sec=120,
cancel_on_timeout=False):
    url = f"{host}/services/search/jobs/{sid}"
    start = datetime.now()
    spinner = ['|', '/', '-', '\\']
    spin = 0

    queued_since = None
    timeout_notified = False
    poll_interval = 2          # fast polling first
    slow_poll_interval = 5     # slower after timeout

    while True:
        r = session.get(url, params={'output_mode': 'json'})
        r.raise_for_status()
        content = r.json()['entry'][0]['content']

        state = content.get('dispatchState')     # QUEUED, RUNNING,
FINALIZING, DONE
        done  = content.get('isDone', False)
        pct   = (content.get('doneProgress') or 0) * 100
        scanned = content.get('scanCount', 0)
        rescnt  = content.get('resultCount', 0)
        run_secs = content.get('runDuration', 0)

        sys.stdout.write(
            f"\r[{spinner[spin % 4]}] State:{state} | Progress:{pct:.1f}% |
"
            f"Scanned:{scanned} | Results:{rescnt} | Run:{run_secs}s | "
            f"Elapsed:{(datetime.now()-start).seconds}s  "
        )
        sys.stdout.flush()
        spin += 1

        # If we're queued, track/how long and optionally change behavior
after timeout
        if state == 'QUEUED':
            if queued_since is None:
                queued_since = datetime.now()

            queued_secs = (datetime.now() - queued_since).seconds

            # Emit diagnostics every ~10s while queued
            if queued_secs % 10 == 0:
                try:
                    msgs =
session.get(f"{host}/services/search/jobs/{sid}/messages",
                                       params={'output_mode':'json'})
                    if msgs.ok:
                        msgs_txt = [e['content']['message'] for e in
msgs.json().get('entry', [])]
                        if msgs_txt:
                            sys.stdout.write(f"\n   ↳ queue msgs: {';
'.join(msgs_txt[:3])}\n")
                except Exception:
                    pass

            # Hit the timeout? Just notify and keep waiting (do NOT
cancel/exit)
            if queued_secs >= queue_timeout_sec and not timeout_notified:
                timeout_notified = True
                sys.stdout.write(
                    f"\n⏳ Still QUEUED after {queue_timeout_sec}s. "
                    f"Continuing to wait (no cancel). Polling every
{slow_poll_interval}s...\n"
                )
                poll_interval = slow_poll_interval

            # Keep looping (don’t cancel, don’t return)
            time.sleep(poll_interval)
            continue

        # Transitioned out of QUEUED → speed back up if we slowed down
        if timeout_notified and poll_interval != 2:
            poll_interval = 2
            sys.stdout.write("\n🚀 Slot acquired. Back to fast polling.\n")

        if done:
            print("\n✅ Search complete.")
            return content  # final job metadata

        time.sleep(poll_interval)
How to use: keep your current call the same:
final_content = wait_for_completion(session, splunk_conf['host'], sid,
queue_timeout_sec=120)
It will not cancel after 120s; it just logs and keeps waiting with slower
polling.

*Adam Peacock*

Principal Architect
Office: +1-214-810-5701


On Sun, Aug 10, 2025 at 7:31 PM Adam Peacock <alawson@aqorn.com> wrote:

>     start = datetime.now()
>     spinner = ['|', '/', '-', '\\']

>         r.raise_for_status()
>         content = r.json()['entry'][0]['content']
>
>         state = content.get('dispatchState')     # QUEUED, RUNNING,
> FINALIZING, DONE, etc.
>         done  = content.get('isDone', False)

    while True:
        # Job status
        r = session.get(url, params={'output_mode': 'json'})
        r.raise_for_status()
        content = r.json()['entry'][0]['content']

        state = content.get('dispatchState')     # QUEUED, RUNNING,
FINALIZING, DONE, etc.
        done  = content.get('isDone', False)
        pct   = (content.get('doneProgress') or 0) * 100
        scanned = content.get('scanCount', 0)
        rescnt  = content.get('resultCount', 0)
        run_secs = content.get('runDuration', 0)

        sys.stdout.write(
            f"\r[{spinner[spin % 4]}] State:{state} | Progress:{pct:.1f}% |
"
            f"Scanned:{scanned} | Results:{rescnt} | Run:{run_secs}s |
Elapsed:{(datetime.now()-start).seconds}s  "
        )
        sys.stdout.flush()
        spin += 1

        # If queued, collect diagnostics every ~10s
        if state == 'QUEUED':
            if queued_since is None:
                queued_since = datetime.now()

            if (datetime.now() - queued_since).seconds % 10 == 0:
                # 1) Job messages (often say "concurrent searches limit
reached" etc.)
                msgs_url = f"{host}/services/search/jobs/{sid}/messages"
                try:
                    m = session.get(msgs_url, params={'output_mode':
'json'})
                    if m.ok:
                        msgs = [e['content']['message'] for e in
m.json().get('entry', [])]
                        if msgs:
                            sys.stdout.write(f"\n   ↳ queue msgs: { ';
'.join(msgs[:3]) }\n")
                except Exception:
                    pass

                # 2) How many searches are running right now?
                running_url = f"{host}/services/search/jobs"
                try:
                    running = session.get(
                        running_url,
                        params={'output_mode':'json',
'search':'dispatchState="RUNNING"', 'count': 0}
                    )
                    if running.ok:
                        total_running = running.json().get('paging',
{}).get('total', '?')
                        sys.stdout.write(f"\n   ↳ running searches:
{total_running}\n")
                except Exception:
                    pass

            # Give up after queue_timeout_sec
            if (datetime.now() - queued_since).seconds >= queue_timeout_sec:
                sys.stdout.write("\n🔴 Still QUEUED after timeout. Exiting
so the job doesn’t hang.\n")
                return content  # Return what we have; caller can decide
next step

        if done:
            print("\n✅ Search complete.")
            return content

        time.sleep(2)

1) Tap live preview rows (proves data is flowing)

Splunk streams interim rows to /results_preview even when the job isn’t
“done.”

python
CopyEdit
def get_preview_status(session, host, sid, sample_rows=3):
    # live, partial results
    url = f"{host}/services/search/jobs/{sid}/results_preview"
    r = session.get(url, params={'output_mode':'json','count': sample_rows})
    r.raise_for_status()
    data = r.json()
    rows = data.get('results', [])
    preview_count = len(rows)

    # job messages (parse warnings, timeouts, subsearch waits, etc.)
    murl = f"{host}/services/search/jobs/{sid}/messages"
    m = session.get(murl, params={'output_mode':'json'})
    msgs = []
    if m.ok:
        try:
            msgs = [e['content']['message'] for e in m.json().get('entry',[])]
        except Exception:
            pass

    return preview_count, rows, msgs

Then, inside your wait_for_completion loop, print a heartbeat every few
seconds:

python
CopyEdit
if spin_idx % 5 == 0:  # every ~10s if you sleep(2)
    pcount, prows, msgs = get_preview_status(session, host, sid)
    sys.stdout.write(f"\n   ↳ preview rows: {pcount}  msgs: {(';
'.join(msgs[:2])) or '—'}\n")
    if prows:
        sys.stdout.write(f"   ↳ first row preview: {prows[0]}\n")

If you see preview rows or new messages, the search is *receiving and
processing data*, even if resultCount is stuck (common for heavy transforms
like stats, sort, etc., which don’t finalize until late).

Robust fix: use a Splunk session key + auto-relogin on 401

Instead of relying on basic auth, log in once to get a *sessionKey* and
send it in the header Authorization: Splunk <sessionKey>. If a 401 happens,
re-login and retry once.

Add these helpers:

python
CopyEdit
import xml.etree.ElementTree as ET
def splunk_login(session, host, username, password):
    # Splunk returns XML: <response><sessionKey>...</sessionKey></response>
    url = f"{host}/services/auth/login"
    r = session.post(url, data={'username': username, 'password':
password}, verify=session.verify)
    r.raise_for_status()
    key = ET.fromstring(r.text).findtext('.//sessionKey')
    if not key:
        raise RuntimeError("Failed to obtain Splunk sessionKey")
    # Use header-based auth from now on
    session.headers.update({'Authorization': f'Splunk {key}'})
    # Remove basic auth so we don't mix methods
    session.auth = None
def splunk_request(session, method, url, **kwargs):
    """Wrapper that retries once on 401 by re-login."""
    r = session.request(method, url, **kwargs)
    if r.status_code == 401:
        # re-login and retry once
        # expects these attrs to be set on session:
        # session._splunk_host, _splunk_user, _splunk_pass
        splunk_login(session, session._splunk_host,
session._splunk_user, session._splunk_pass)
        r = session.request(method, url, **kwargs)
    r.raise_for_status()
    return r

Modify your session initializer:

python
CopyEdit
def get_splunk_session(splunk_conf):
    session = requests.Session()
    session.verify = False  # or a cert path
    # stash creds for relogin
    session._splunk_host = splunk_conf['host']
    session._splunk_user = splunk_conf['username']
    session._splunk_pass = splunk_conf['password']
    # login to get sessionKey
    splunk_login(session, splunk_conf['host'],
splunk_conf['username'], splunk_conf['password'])
    return session

Then replace direct session.get/post calls with splunk_request:

python
CopyEdit
# submit_searchdef submit_search(session, query, host, job_conf):
    url = f"{host}/services/search/jobs"
    data = {
        'search': query,
        'output_mode': 'json',
        'exec_mode': 'normal',
        'status_buckets': 0,
        'rf': ['_time','_raw'],
    }
    # (optional search_mode handling you added earlier)
    r = splunk_request(session, 'POST', url, data=data)
    return r.json()['sid']
# wait_for_completion loop
r = splunk_request(session, 'GET', f"{host}/services/search/jobs/{sid}",
                   params={'output_mode': 'json'})
# results / messages / preview / search.log
r = splunk_request(session, 'GET', f"{host}/services/search/jobs/{sid}/results",
                   params={'output_mode': 'json', 'count': count,
'offset': offset})

input: Subject: Code

def submit_search(session, query, host, job_conf):
    url = f"{host}/services/search/jobs"

    # Prepend 'search ' if needed
    if not query.strip().lower().startswith(('search', '|', 'tstats',
'inputlookup', 'metadata', 'from')):
        query = 'search ' + query.strip()

    # Read optional search_mode; only allow known-good values
    wanted_mode = job_conf['QUERY'].get('search_mode', 'fast').lower()
    allowed_modes = {'fast', 'smart', 'verbose'}  # common UI modes; some
servers don't accept any
    use_mode = wanted_mode if wanted_mode in allowed_modes else None

    # Base payload
    data = {
        'search': query,
        'output_mode': 'json',
        'exec_mode': 'normal',
        # Emulate "fast" behavior regardless of server support:
        # - don't build status buckets
        # - only return required fields unless the SPL asks for more
        'status_buckets': 0,
        'rf': ['_time', '_raw']  # you can add other fields you always need
    }

    # Add search_mode only if we think it’s supported
    if use_mode:
        data['search_mode'] = use_mode

    # First attempt
    response = session.post(url, data=data)
    if response.status_code == 201:
        return response.json()['sid']

    # If server complains about search_mode, retry without it
    txt = response.text.lower()
    if ('invalid search mode' in txt or 'search_mode' in txt) and
'search_mode' in data:
        data.pop('search_mode', None)
        response = session.post(url, data=data)
        if response.status_code == 201:
            return response.json()['sid']

    # Still not happy -> show server message
    print("\n🔴 Error submitting search:")
    print(f"Status: {response.status_code}")
    print(f"Response: {response.text}")
    response.raise_for_status()

*Adam Peacock*

def wait_for_completion(session, host, sid):
    url = f"{host}/services/search/jobs/{sid}"
    start_time = datetime.now()
    spinner = ['|', '/', '-', '\\']
    spin_idx = 0

    while True:
        # Get job status
        response = session.get(url, params={'output_mode': 'json'})
        content = response.json()['entry'][0]['content']

        is_done = content['isDone']
        percent = content.get('doneProgress', 0) * 100
        scanned = content.get('scanCount', '?')
        event_count = content.get('eventCount', '?')
        result_count = content.get('resultCount', '?')
        dispatch_state = content.get('dispatchState')
        run_secs = content.get('runDuration')
        elapsed = datetime.now() - start_time

        # Progress line
        sys.stdout.write(
            f"\r[{spinner[spin_idx % 4]}] State:{dispatch_state} |
Progress:{percent:.1f}% "
            f"| Scanned:{scanned} | Matched:{event_count} |
Results:{result_count} "
            f"| Run:{run_secs}s | Elapsed:{str(elapsed).split('.')[0]}  "
        )
        sys.stdout.flush()
        spin_idx += 1

        # 🔍 Every ~10 seconds, check preview results
        if spin_idx % 5 == 0:  # 5 * sleep(2) = ~10 seconds
            pcount, prows, msgs = get_preview_status(session, host, sid)
            sys.stdout.write(f"\n   ↳ preview rows: {pcount}  msgs: {(';
'.join(msgs[:2])) or '—'}\n")
            if prows:
                sys.stdout.write(f"   ↳ first preview row: {prows[0]}\n")

        if is_done:
            print("\n✅ Search complete.")
            return content  # Return final job metadata

        time.sleep(2)

*Adam Peacock*

*1️⃣ Add datetime import*

At the top of your script, make sure this is present:

python
CopyEdit
from datetime import datetime

------------------------------
*2️⃣ Modify wait_for_completion() to return job metadata*

You already have this function — just make sure it *returns* the final
content dictionary so we can access resultCountand dispatchTime:

python
CopyEdit
def wait_for_completion(session, host, sid):
    url = f"{host}/services/search/jobs/{sid}"
    start_time = datetime.now()
    spinner = ['|', '/', '-', '\\']
    spin_idx = 0

    while True:
        response = session.get(url, params={'output_mode': 'json'})
        content = response.json()['entry'][0]['content']

        is_done = content['isDone']
        percent = content.get('doneProgress', 0) * 100
        scanned = content.get('scanCount', '?')
        event_count = content.get('eventCount', '?')
        result_count = content.get('resultCount', '?')
        elapsed = datetime.now() - start_time

        sys.stdout.write(
            f"\r[{spinner[spin_idx % 4]}] "
            f"Progress: {percent:.1f}% | Scanned: {scanned} | "
            f"Matched: {event_count} | Results: {result_count} |
Elapsed: {str(elapsed).split('.')[0]}  "
        )
        sys.stdout.flush()
        spin_idx += 1

        if is_done:
            print("\n✅ Search complete.")
            return content  # <-- NEW: return job metadata

        time.sleep(2)

------------------------------
*3️⃣ Create a new insert_count_mysql()*

This function inserts *only result_count and timestamp* into the MySQL
table:

python
CopyEdit
def insert_count_mysql(result_count, dispatch_time, static_mysql_conf,
dynamic_mysql_conf):
    conn = pymysql.connect(
        host=static_mysql_conf['host'],
        user=static_mysql_conf['user'],
        password=static_mysql_conf['password'],
        database=dynamic_mysql_conf['database']
    )
    cursor = conn.cursor()
    table = dynamic_mysql_conf['table']

    # Simple schema for count-only mode
    create_stmt = f"""
    CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS {table} (
        id INT AUTO_INCREMENT PRIMARY KEY,
        ts DATETIME NOT NULL,
        result_count BIGINT NOT NULL
    )
    """
    cursor.execute(create_stmt)

    insert_stmt = f"INSERT INTO {table} (ts, result_count) VALUES (%s, %s)"
    cursor.execute(insert_stmt, (dispatch_time, int(result_count)))

    conn.commit()
    cursor.close()
    conn.close()

------------------------------
*4️⃣ Update the main block*

You’ll make *three updates* here.

*a) Read the count_only flag from job.ini:*

python
CopyEdit
count_only = job_conf['QUERY'].get('count_only',
'false').strip().lower() in ('1', 'true', 'yes')

*b) After wait_for_completion(), extract the count and timestamp:*

python
CopyEdit
final_content = wait_for_completion(session, splunk_conf['host'], sid)
result_count = final_content.get('resultCount', 0)
# Parse Splunk's dispatch time
dispatch_time_str = final_content.get('dispatchTime')if dispatch_time_str:
    try:
        dispatch_time =
datetime.fromisoformat(dispatch_time_str.replace("Z", "+00:00"))
    except Exception:
        dispatch_time = datetime.utcnow()else:
    dispatch_time = datetime.utcnow()

*c) Add conditional logic for count-only mode:*

python
CopyEdit
if count_only:
    print(f"\nCount-only mode: result_count={result_count},
dispatch_time={dispatch_time}. Writing to DB...")
    insert_count_mysql(result_count, dispatch_time, static_mysql_conf,
dynamic_mysql_conf)
    print("✅ Count + timestamp saved to MySQL.")else:
    results = get_results(session, splunk_conf['host'], sid)
    print(f"\nFetched {len(results)} results.")
    insert_results_mysql(results, static_mysql_conf, dynamic_mysql_conf)
    print("✅ Data saved to MySQL.")

------------------------------

ini

def submit_search(session, query, host, job_conf):
    """
    Create a Splunk search job with safe defaults and fast-mode behavior.
    Requires `splunk_request()` helper and a session authenticated via
sessionKey.
    """

    # Ensure API-friendly SPL (UI auto-adds 'search', API does not)
    q = query.strip()
    if not q.lower().startswith(('search', '|', 'tstats', 'inputlookup',
'metadata', 'from')):
        q = 'search ' + q

    url = f"{host}/services/search/jobs"

    # Optional search_mode from job.ini (fast/smart/verbose); some servers
reject it.
    wanted_mode = job_conf['QUERY'].get('search_mode', 'fast').lower()
    allowed_modes = {'fast', 'smart', 'verbose'}
    use_mode = wanted_mode if wanted_mode in allowed_modes else None

    # Base payload: emulate "fast" performance characteristics
    data = {
        'search': q,
        'output_mode': 'json',
        'exec_mode': 'normal',     # 'normal' | 'blocking' | 'oneshot'
        'status_buckets': 0,       # reduce overhead
        'rf': ['_time', '_raw']    # limit required fields; add more if you
always need them
    }
    if use_mode:
        data['search_mode'] = use_mode

    # First attempt
    r = splunk_request(session, 'POST', url, data=data)
    if r.status_code == 201:
        return r.json()['sid']

    # If server complains about search_mode, retry without it
    err_text = r.text.lower()
    if ('invalid search mode' in err_text or 'search_mode' in err_text) and
'search_mode' in data:
        data.pop('search_mode', None)
        r = splunk_request(session, 'POST', url, data=data)
        if r.status_code == 201:
            return r.json()['sid']

    # Bubble up detailed error
    print("\n🔴 Error submitting search:")
    print(f"Status: {r.status_code}")
    print(f"Response: {r.text}")
    r.raise_for_status()

*Adam Peacock*

Principal Architect
Office: +1-214-810-5701


On Sun, Aug 10, 2025 at 8:13 PM Adam Peacock <alawson@aqorn.com> wrote:

> Robust fix: use a Splunk session key + auto-relogin on 401
>
> Instead of relying on basic auth, log in once to get a *sessionKey* and
> send it in the header Authorization: Splunk <sessionKey>. If a 401
> happens, re-login and retry once.
>
> Add these helpers:
>
> python
> CopyEdit
> import xml.etree.ElementTree as ET
> def splunk_login(session, host, username, password):
>     # Splunk returns XML: <response><sessionKey>...</sessionKey></response>
>     url = f"{host}/services/auth/login"
>     r = session.post(url, data={'username': username, 'password': password}, verify=session.verify)
>     r.raise_for_status()
>     key = ET.fromstring(r.text).findtext('.//sessionKey')
>     if not key:
>         raise RuntimeError("Failed to obtain Splunk sessionKey")
>     # Use header-based auth from now on
>     session.headers.update({'Authorization': f'Splunk {key}'})
>     # Remove basic auth so we don't mix methods
>     session.auth = None
> def splunk_request(session, method, url, **kwargs):
>     """Wrapper that retries once on 401 by re-login."""
>     r = session.request(method, url, **kwargs)
>     if r.status_code == 401:
>         # re-login and retry once
>         # expects these attrs to be set on session:
>         # session._splunk_host, _splunk_user, _splunk_pass
>         splunk_login(session, session._splunk_host, session._splunk_user, session._splunk_pass)
>         r = session.request(method, url, **kwargs)
>     r.raise_for_status()
>     return r
>
> Modify your session initializer:
>
> python
> CopyEdit
> def get_splunk_session(splunk_conf):
>     session = requests.Session()
>     session.verify = False  # or a cert path
>     # stash creds for relogin
>     session._splunk_host = splunk_conf['host']
>     session._splunk_user = splunk_conf['username']
>     session._splunk_pass = splunk_conf['password']
>     # login to get sessionKey

instruction: Write a professional email to: adam.peacock@transunion.com
input: Subject: query code
output:
import os
import time
import requests
import pymysql
import json

# === CONFIGURATION ===
SPLUNK_HOST = "https://your-splunk-host:8089"
SPLUNK_USERNAME = "admin"
SPLUNK_PASSWORD = os.getenv('SPLUNK_PASSWORD')  # Secure
SPLUNK_QUERY = 'search index=_internal | head 10000'

MYSQL_CONFIG = {
    'host': 'localhost',
    'user': 'root',
    'password': os.getenv('MYSQL_PASSWORD'),  # Secure
    'database': 'splunk_data'
}
MYSQL_TABLE = 'splunk_results'

# === FUNCTIONS ===

def get_auth_session():
    if not SPLUNK_PASSWORD:
        raise ValueError("Missing SPLUNK_PASSWORD environment variable")
    session = requests.Session()
    session.auth = (SPLUNK_USERNAME, SPLUNK_PASSWORD)
    session.verify = False
    return session

def submit_search(session, query):
    url = f"{SPLUNK_HOST}/services/search/jobs"
    data = {'search': query, 'output_mode': 'json'}
    response = session.post(url, data=data)
    response.raise_for_status()
    return response.json()['sid']

def wait_for_completion(session, sid):
    while True:
        url = f"{SPLUNK_HOST}/services/search/jobs/{sid}"
        response = session.get(url, params={'output_mode': 'json'})
        content = response.json()
        if content['entry'][0]['content']['isDone']:
            break
        time.sleep(2)

def get_results(session, sid):
    results = []
    offset = 0
    count = 50000
    while True:
        url = f"{SPLUNK_HOST}/services/search/jobs/{sid}/results"
        params = {'output_mode': 'json', 'count': count, 'offset': offset}
        response = session.get(url, params=params)
        response.raise_for_status()
        chunk = response.json()['results']
        if not chunk:
            break
        results.extend(chunk)
        offset += len(chunk)
    return results

def insert_results_mysql(results):
    if not MYSQL_CONFIG['password']:
        raise ValueError("Missing MYSQL_PASSWORD environment variable")
    conn = pymysql.connect(**MYSQL_CONFIG)
    cursor = conn.cursor()

    if results:
        keys = results[0].keys()
        create_stmt = f"""
        CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS {MYSQL_TABLE} (
            id INT AUTO_INCREMENT PRIMARY KEY,
            {', '.join(f'{k} TEXT' for k in keys)}
        )
        """
        cursor.execute(create_stmt)

        for row in results:
            cols = ', '.join(row.keys())
            placeholders = ', '.join(['%s'] * len(row))
            values = [str(v) for v in row.values()]
            insert_stmt = f"INSERT INTO {MYSQL_TABLE} ({cols}) VALUES
({placeholders})"
            cursor.execute(insert_stmt, values)

        conn.commit()
    cursor.close()
    conn.close()

# === MAIN EXECUTION ===

if __name__ == '__main__':
    session = get_auth_session()
    sid = submit_search(session, SPLUNK_QUERY)
    print(f"Search SID: {sid}")
    wait_for_completion(session, sid)
    results = get_results(session, sid)
    print(f"Fetched {len(results)} results.")
    insert_results_mysql(results)
    print("Data saved to MySQL.")

*Adam Peacock*

Principal Architect
Office: +1-214-810-5701

import sys
import datetime

def wait_for_completion(session, sid):
    url = f"{SPLUNK_HOST}/services/search/jobs/{sid}"
    start_time = datetime.datetime.now()
    spinner = ['|', '/', '-', '\\']
    spin_idx = 0

    while True:
        response = session.get(url, params={'output_mode': 'json'})
        content = response.json()['entry'][0]['content']

        is_done = content['isDone']
        percent = content.get('doneProgress', 0) * 100
        event_count = content.get('eventCount', '?')
        result_count = content.get('resultCount', '?')
        scanned = content.get('scanCount', '?')
        elapsed = datetime.datetime.now() - start_time

        sys.stdout.write(
            f"\r[{spinner[spin_idx % 4]}] "
            f"Progress: {percent:.1f}% | Events scanned: {scanned} | "
            f"Matched: {event_count} | Results: {result_count} | Elapsed:
{str(elapsed).split('.')[0]}  "
        )
        sys.stdout.flush()
        spin_idx += 1

        if is_done:
            print("\n✅ Search complete.")
            break

        time.sleep(2)

import time
import sys
import json
import argparse
import configparser
import requests
import pymysql
import datetime
import urllib3

# Disable SSL warnings (use only in dev/test)
urllib3.disable_warnings(urllib3.exceptions.InsecureRequestWarning)

# === CONFIG LOADING ===

def load_ini_config(file_path):
    config = configparser.ConfigParser()
    config.read(file_path)
    return config

# === SPLUNK FUNCTIONS ===

def get_splunk_session(splunk_conf):
    session = requests.Session()
    session.auth = (splunk_conf['username'], splunk_conf['password'])
    session.verify = False  # Only for self-signed certs in dev/test
    return session

def submit_search(session, query, host):
    url = f"{host}/services/search/jobs"
    data = {'search': query, 'output_mode': 'json'}
    response = session.post(url, data=data)
    response.raise_for_status()
    return response.json()['sid']

def wait_for_completion(session, host, sid):
    url = f"{host}/services/search/jobs/{sid}"
    start_time = datetime.datetime.now()
    spinner = ['|', '/', '-', '\\']
    spin_idx = 0

    while True:
        response = session.get(url, params={'output_mode': 'json'})
        content = response.json()['entry'][0]['content']

        is_done = content['isDone']
        percent = content.get('doneProgress', 0) * 100
        scanned = content.get('scanCount', '?')
        event_count = content.get('eventCount', '?')
        result_count = content.get('resultCount', '?')
        elapsed = datetime.datetime.now() - start_time

        sys.stdout.write(
            f"\r[{spinner[spin_idx % 4]}] "
            f"Progress: {percent:.1f}% | Scanned: {scanned} | "
            f"Matched: {event_count} | Results: {result_count} | Elapsed:
{str(elapsed).split('.')[0]}  "
        )
        sys.stdout.flush()
        spin_idx += 1

        if is_done:
            print("\n✅ Search complete.")
            break
        time.sleep(2)

def get_results(session, host, sid):
    results = []
    offset = 0
    count = 50000
    while True:
        url = f"{host}/services/search/jobs/{sid}/results"
        params = {'output_mode': 'json', 'count': count, 'offset': offset}
        response = session.get(url, params=params)
        response.raise_for_status()
        chunk = response.json()['results']
        if not chunk:
            break
        results.extend(chunk)
        offset += len(chunk)
    return results

# === MYSQL FUNCTIONS ===

def insert_results_mysql(results, static_mysql_conf, dynamic_mysql_conf):
    conn = pymysql.connect(
        host=static_mysql_conf['host'],
        user=static_mysql_conf['user'],
        password=static_mysql_conf['password'],
        database=dynamic_mysql_conf['database']
    )
    cursor = conn.cursor()
    table = dynamic_mysql_conf['table']

    if results:
        keys = results[0].keys()
        create_stmt = f"""
        CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS {table} (
            id INT AUTO_INCREMENT PRIMARY KEY,
            {', '.join(f'{k} TEXT' for k in keys)}
        )
        """
        cursor.execute(create_stmt)

        for row in results:
            cols = ', '.join(row.keys())
            placeholders = ', '.join(['%s'] * len(row))
            values = [str(v) for v in row.values()]
            insert_stmt = f"INSERT INTO {table} ({cols}) VALUES
({placeholders})"
            cursor.execute(insert_stmt, values)

        conn.commit()
    cursor.close()
    conn.close()

# === MAIN SCRIPT ===

if __name__ == '__main__':
    parser = argparse.ArgumentParser(description="Run Splunk query and
export to MySQL")
    parser.add_argument('--job-config', required=True, help='Path to
job-specific .ini file (e.g., job1.ini)')
    args = parser.parse_args()

    # Load configuration files
    static_conf = load_ini_config('splunk.ini')
    job_conf = load_ini_config(args.job_config)

    # Ext

> intelligence (AI) and machine learning (ML) solutions. This position

> architecture, with a proven track record of delivering scalable AI

>    including data pipelines, model development, deployment, and integration
>    into enterprise systems.

>    scientists, engineers, and developers to deliver AI solutions, providing
>    technical guidance and mentorship.
>    - *Solution Development*: Design and implement advanced AI models
>    (e.g., deep learning, NLP, computer vision) tailored to business use cases.
>
> *Required Qualifications*
>

>    software engineering, or related fields, with at least 5 years in an AI
>    architecture or leadership role.
>    - *Education*: Bachelor’s degree in computer science, Data Science,
>    Engineering, or a related field. Master’s or Ph.D. in AI, Machine Learning,
>    or a related discipline is preferred.

>       Scikit-learn).
>       - Open AI , Chat GPT and Prompt engineering
>       - Proficiency in programming languages (e.g., Python, Java, C++).
>       - Strong knowledge of cloud platforms (e.g., AWS, Azure, GCP) and
>       their AI/ML services.
>       - Experience with big data technologies (e.g., Hadoop, Spark,
>       Kafka).

>       engineering pipelines.

>    Learning, Google Cloud Professional ML Engineer).
>    - Experience with generative AI, reinforcement learning, or advanced
>    NLP techniques.
>    - Contributions to open-source AI projects or publications in AI/ML
>    conferences/journals.
>    - Familiarity with agile methodologies and DevOps practices.
>
>
>
>
